{{Infobox company | name = Mayer Hoffman McCann P.C. | location = [[Kansas City]], [[Missouri]], [[United States]] | foundation = 1954 | industry = [[Accounting]] | key_people = Andy Burczyk, President | products = [[Professional services]] | homepage = [http://www.mhmcpa.com/ www.mhmcpa.com] }} '''Mayer Hoffman McCann P.C. (MHM)''' is a national [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]] firm founded and headquartered in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. MHM has over 30 offices in the [[United States]].<ref>[http://www.mhmcpa.com/Locations.aspx MHM Website - MHM Locations]</ref> MHM is a member of Kreston International,<ref>[http://kreston.com/find-a-member/ Kreston Website - Find Members]</ref> a member of the [[Forum of Firms]], which has more than 21,000 professionals in over 110 countries.<ref>[http://kreston.com/about-us/ Kreston Website - About Us]</ref>
==Early history== MHM dates back to 1954 with Ernst D. Mayer in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. In 1960 the practice merged with Bill Hoffman’s practice. MHM officially became Mayer Hoffman McCann in 1978 when Chuck McCann was added as a managing partner.<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/news/2014/02/27/bar-is-set-high-for-new-local-cbiz.html?page=all Bar is set high for new local CBIZ manager]</ref>
==Association with CBIZ, Inc.== * In 1998 MHM spun off its tax and consulting practice, which was merged into Century Business Services, Inc, now known as CBIZ, Inc.<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/stories/1998/08/10/story8.html Cleveland public company to acquire Mayer Hoffman]</ref> That tax and consulting practice now operates as CBIZ MHM, LLC (a division of parent company CBIZ, Inc.). MHM maintains an association with CBIZ through an administrative services agreement and practices public accounting through an alternative practice structure as defined in [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] (AICPA) Ethics Interpretation 101-14. However, MHM is owned and managed by its CPA shareholders. *MHM (Mayer Hoffman McCann) and CBIZ are ranked by [[Accounting Today]] as one of the top national accounting providers in the country, ranking #10 in the 2016 ranking that was issued in spring of 2016.<ref>[http://pages.marketing.accountingtoday.com/act_77340_sr_lp.html The 2016 AccountingToday Top 100 Firms]</ref>
==Industries== MHM provides audit and attest services to industries<ref>[http://www.mhmcpa.com/Industries/Overview.aspx MHM Website - Industries Served by MHM]</ref> including: *Architecture, engineering and construction *Manufacturing, retail and distribution *Government *Financial Institutions *Software, high-tech and life sciences *Not-for-profit
==Other== MHM is licensed in all 50 states and a member of the AICPA's [[Center for Audit Quality]], the Employee Benefit Plan Audit Quality Center, the Governmental Audit Quality Center and the [[Canadian Public Accountability Board]].<ref>[http://www.mhmcpa.com/About-MHM/Overview.aspx MHM Website - About MHM]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mhmcpa.com MHM]
[[Category:Accounting firms of the United States]]

{{otherpeople|Thomas Donovan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = Paddy Donovan | image = | alt = | caption = | headercolor = | textcolor = | full_name = Thomas Patrick Donovan | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|12|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]], New Zealand | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|03|11|1936|12|23|df=yes}} | death_place = Napier, New Zealand | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | occupation = [[Accountant]] | height = {{convert|5|ft|4+1/2|in|m|2|abbr=on|order=flip}} | weight = {{convert|59|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | spouse = | country = New Zealand | sport = [[Amateur boxing]] | weight_class = | weight_class_type = | rank = | club = | team = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | nationals = Featherweight champion (1954)
Lightweight champion (1956, 1957, 1959, 1962) | commonwealth = | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{NZL}}}} {{MedalSport|Men's [[boxing]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[British Empire Games]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1958 Cardiff]]|[[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games#Boxing|Lightweight]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 Perth]]|[[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games#Boxing|Lightweight]]}} }} '''Thomas Patrick Donovan''' (23 December 1936 – 11 March 2018) was a New Zealand [[amateur boxer]] and [[rugby union]] player. He represented his country in boxing at the [[Boxing at the 1956 Summer Olympics|1956]] and [[Boxing at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Olympic Games]], and won bronze medals at the [[Boxing at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1958]] and [[Boxing at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]]. He also played representative rugby for {{Rut Hawke's Bay}}. ==Early life and family== Born in [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] on 23 December 1936, Donovan was the son of Tommy Donovan, who won the 1927 New Zealand amateur featherweight boxing title, and then had 46 professional bouts between 1929 and 1935.{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12012003 |title=Olympics boxer Paddy Donovan dies in Napier |date=13 March 2018 |work=Hawke's Bay Today |first=Doug |last=Laing |accessdate=27 March 2018}} Paddy Donovan grew up on his family's farm at Meeanee, and was educated at [[St John's College, Hastings]], where he was head boy. ==Boxing== Donovan won his first national amateur boxing title, in the featherweight division, in 1954, while he was still at school. He went on to win the national lightweight title four times—in 1956, 1957, 1959, and 1962—and he was awarded the Jameson Belt for the most scientific boxer in 1956, 1959, and 1962. Donovan won the bronze medal in the men's 57–60 kg (lightweight) division at the [[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]]. Four years later at the [[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] he again won the bronze medal in the same division.{{cite web |url=http://www.olympic.org.nz/athletes/paddy-donovan/ |title=Paddy Donovan |year=2018 |publisher=New Zealand Olympic Committee | accessdate=27 March 2018}} He competed at two [[Summer Olympic Games|Olympics]], not making it past the first round of the lightweight division in [[Boxing at the 1956 Summer Olympics|1956]] and [[Boxing at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964]],{{Cite sports-reference | Paddy Donovan | https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/do/paddy-donovan-1.html | 27 March 2018}} and was controversially omitted from the New Zealand team for the [[New Zealand at the 1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Olympics]]. ==1956 and 1964 Olympic results== Below is the record of Paddy Donovan, a lightweight boxer from New Zealand, who competed at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics: * Round of 32: lost to Toshihito Ishimaru (Japan) on points Below is the record of Paddy Donovan, a lightweight boxer from New Zealand, who competed at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics: * Round of 32: lost to Hector Pace (Argentina) referee stopped contest ==Rugby union== A [[Rugby union positions#Scrum-half|halfback]] and [[Rugby union positions#Fly-half|first five-eighth]], Donovan played for the {{Rut Hawke's Bay}} rugby union team between 1955 and 1959. ==Later life and death== From 1962, Donovan worked as an [[accountant]] in [[Hastings, New Zealand|Hastings]], retiring in 2012 after 50 years. In 2001, he established Ballydooley Cider Ltd on the family orchard. Donovan died in Napier on 11 March 2018. ==References== {{reflist}} {{1956 New Zealand Olympic team}} {{1958 New Zealand British Empire and Commonwealth Games team}} {{1964 New Zealand Olympic team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Donovan, Paddy}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Napier, New Zealand]] [[Category:People educated at St John's College, Hastings]] [[Category:Olympic boxers of New Zealand]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games bronze medallists for New Zealand]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1964 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:New Zealand male boxers]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in boxing]] [[Category:Hawke's Bay Magpies players]] [[Category:Rugby union scrum-halves]] [[Category:Rugby union fly-halves]] [[Category:New Zealand accountants]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Rugby union players from Napier, New Zealand]]

{{More citations needed|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Paul Rosenfeld | birth_date = May 4, 1890 | birth_place = [[New York City]] | death_date = July 21, 1946 (age 56) | death_place = [[New York City]] | death_cause = | nationality = American | education = | home_town = | residence = | spouse = | known_for = Music critic | occupation = Journalist | children = | parents = Clara Liebmann Rosenfield
Julius Rosenfield | family = [[Samuel Liebmann]] (great grandfather) }} '''Paul Leopold Rosenfeld''' (May 4, 1890 – July 21, 1946) was an American [[journalist]], best known as a [[music critic]].{{Cite web|last=Brennan |first=Marcia |authorlink= |title= Alfred Stieglitz and Paul Rosenfeld – An Aesthetics of Intimacy |publisher=Rice University – History of Photography, Volume 23, Number 1, Spring 1999 |date= |url=https://scholarship.rice.edu/bitstream/handle/1911/70695/An-Aesthetics-of-Intimacy.pdf?sequence=3 |accessdate=}} ==Biography== He was born in [[New York City]] into a German-Jewish family, the son of Clara (née Liebmann) and Julius Rosenfield. His mother was the granddaughter of brewer [[Samuel Liebmann]]. He studied at [[Riverview Military Academy]], [[Poughkeepsie (city), New York|Poughkeepsie]], and [[Yale University]], graduating in 1912. After further education at the [[Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism]], he became a prolific journalist, writing on literature and art as well as music. He was one of the [[Alfred Stieglitz]] circle, and favoured an intellectually heavyweight and quite European approach. His friend [[Edmund Wilson]], writing two years after Rosenfeld's death, expressed the thought that his articles had become too uncompromising for the public taste, as time went by. Indeed, these days Rosenfeld is probably more famous for having inspired Wilson's tribute — republished in ''Classics and Commercials'' (1950) — than for anything he himself produced. Magazines which published Rosenfeld's writing included ''[[The New Republic]]'', ''[[Seven Arts]]'', ''[[Vanity Fair magazine]]'', ''[[The Nation (U.S. periodical)|The Nation]]'', ''[[The Dial]]'' and ''[[Modern Music (magazine)|Modern Music]]''. He edited ''Seven Arts'' from 1916 to 1918, and was an editor of the ''American Caravan'' yearbooks. ''The Boy in the Sun'' (1928) was an [[autobiographical novel]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Gutenberg author | id=Rosenfeld,+Paul | name=Paul Rosenfeld}} * {{FadedPage|id=Rosenfeld, Paul|name=Paul Rosenfeld|author=yes}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Paul Leopold Rosenfeld}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rosenfeld, Paul}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:Jewish American journalists]] [[Category:American music critics]] [[Category:American music journalists]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:American people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:Liebmann family]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]]

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=The math notation in this article is a mess and some of the phrasing is insulting to the reader.|date=February 2013}} {{expert needed|date=February 2013}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2018}} }}
The '''profit model''' is the linear, deterministic algebraic model used implicitly by most [[cost accounting|cost accountants]]. Starting with, profit equals sales minus costs, it provides a structure for modeling cost elements such as materials, losses, multi-products, learning, depreciation etc. It provides a mutable conceptual base for spreadsheet modelers. This enables them to run deterministic simulations or '[[What-if analysis|what if]]' modelling to see the impact of price, cost or quantity changes on profitability.
==Basic model==
: <math> \pi = pq - (F_n+wq) \, </math>
where:
: {{pi}} is profit : ''p'' is sales price : ''F''<sub>''n''</sub> is fixed costs : ''w'' is variable costs per unit sold : ''q'' is quantity sold
For an expansion of the model see below.
== Background == The justification for wanting to express profit as an [[algebra]]ic model is given by [[Richard Mattessich|Mattessich]] in 1961: :'To some operations analysts the mere translation of accounting models into mathematical :terminology, without a calculus for determining an optimum, might appear to be a rather :pedestrian task. We are convinced, however, that as long as accounting methods are acceptable :to the industry the mere change to a mathematical formulation will be advantageous for :several reasons: (1) it can be considered a prerequisite for applying electronic data :processing to certain accounting problems, (2) it articulates the structure of the accounting :models and illuminates accounting methods from a new point of view, revealing many facets so :far neglected or unobserved, (3) it enables a general and hence more scientific presentation :of many accounting methods, (4) it facilitates the exploration of new areas, thereby :accelerating the advancement of accounting, (5) it leads to more sophisticated methods and :might help to lay the foundations for close cooperation of accounting with other areas of :management science.'<ref name=Matt>Mattessich, R. (1961). 'Budgeting models and system simulation', The Accounting Review, 36(3), 384–397.</ref>
Most of the definitions in cost accounting are in an unclear narrative form, not readily associated with other definitions of accounting calculations. For example, preparing a comparison of fixed cost variances in stock under different stock valuation methods can be confusing. Another example is modelling labour variances with learning curve corrections and stock level changes. With the absence of a basic profit model in an algebraic form, confident development of such models is difficult.
The development of spreadsheets has led to a decentralisation of financial modelling. This has often resulted in model builders lacking training in model construction. Before any professional model is built it is usually considered wise to start by developing a mathematical model for analysis. The profit model provides a general framework plus some specific examples of how such an a priori profit model might be constructed.
The presentation of a profit model in an algebraic form is not new. Mattessich's model,<ref name=Matt /> while large, does not include many costing techniques such as learning curves and different stock valuation methods. Also, it was not presented in a form that most accountants were willing or able to read. This paper presents a more extended model analysing profit but it does not, unlike Mattessich, extend to the balance sheet model. Its form, of starting with the basic definition of profit and becoming more elaborate, may make it more accessible to accountants.
Most cost accounting textbooks <ref>Drury, C. (1988). Management and Cost Accounting, London: V.N.R</ref> explain basic Cost Volume Profit modeling in an algebraic form, but then revert to an 'illustrative' <ref>Ijiri, Y. (1983). 'New dimensions in accounting education: computers and algorithms,' Issues In Accounting Research, 168–173.</ref> approach. This 'illustrative' approach uses examples or narrative to explain management accounting procedures. This format, though useful when communicating with humans, can be difficult to translate into an algebraic form, suitable for computer model building. Mepham <ref>Mepham, M. (1980). Accounting Models, London: Pitmans</ref> extended the algebraic, or deductive, approach to cost accounting to cover many more techniques. He develops his model to integrate with the optimizing models in operations research. The profit model comes out of Mephams work, extending it but only in a descriptive, linear form.
== Model extensions == The basic profit model is sales minus costs. Sales are made up of quantity sold multiplied by their price. Costs are usually divided between Fixed costs and variable costs.
Using: * Sales revenue = ''pq'' = price × quantity sold * Cost of sales = ''wq'' = unit cost × quantity sold *Administration, selling, engineers, personnel etc. = ''Fn'' = fixed post-manufacturing overheads *Profit = ''π''
Thus the profit can be calculated from:
: <math> \pi = pq - (F_n + wq) \qquad\qquad (1) </math>
Notice that ''w'' (average unit production cost) includes the fixed and variable costs. The square brackets contain the cost of goods sold, ''wq'' not cost of good made ''wx'' where ''x'' = cost of good sold.
To show cost of good sold, the opening and closing finished goods stocks need to be included The profit model would then be:
* Opening stock = ''g''<sub>o</sub> ''w'' = opening stock quantity × unit cost * Cost of stock = ''g''<sub>1</sub> ''w'' = closing stock quantity × unit cost * Cost of production = ''wx'' = unit production cost × quantity made:
: <math> \pi = pq - [F_n + wx + g_0 w - g_1 w] \qquad\qquad (2) </math>
Presenting the profit calculation in this form immediately demands that some of the costs be more carefully defined.
=== Production costs === The unit production costs (''w'') can be separated into fixed and variable costs:
: <math> w = \frac{F_m + vx}{x} \qquad\qquad (3) </math>
where
* ''F''<sub>''m''</sub> = manufacturing fixed costs; * ''v'' = variable costs per unit; * ''x'' = production quantity.
The introduction of this separation of ''w'' allows for consideration of the behaviour of costs for different levels of production. A linear cost curve is assumed here, divided between the constant (''F'') and its slope (''v''). If the modeller has access to the details of non-linear cost curves then ''w'' will need to be defined by the appropriate function.
Replacing ''wx'' in (equation 2) and making ''F'' = ''F''<sub>''n''</sub> + ''F''<sub>''m''</sub>:
: <math> \pi = pq - [F + vx + g0w - g1w] \qquad \qquad (4) </math>
=== Variable-cost elements === Moving on to other extensions of the basic model, the cost elements such as direct materials, direct labour and variable overheads can be included. If a non-linear function is available and thought useful such functions can be substituted for the functions used here.
The material cost of sales = m * µ * q, where
m is the amount of material in one unit of finished goods.
µ is the cost per unit of the raw material.
The labour cost of sales = ''l λ q'', where
* ''l'' is the amount of labour hours required to make one unit of finished goods * ''λ'' is the labour cost (rate) per hour.
The variable overhead cost of sales = ''nq'' where ''n'' is the variable overhead cost per unit.
This is not here subdivided between quantity per finished goods units and cost per unit.
Thus the variable cost v * q can now be elaborated into:
: π = pq - [F+(mµ q + l λq + nq)] …………(equation 5)
If the production quantity is required the finished goods stock will need to be added.
In a simple case two materials can be accommodated in the model by simply adding another m * µ. In more realistic situations a matrix and a vector will be necessary (see later).
If material cost of purchases is to be used rather than material cost of production it will be necessary to adjust for material stocks. That is,
: mx = md<sub>0</sub> + mb - md<sub>1</sub>………… (equation 6)
where * d = material stock quantity, * 0 = opening, 1 = closing, * b = quantity of material purchased * m = the amount of material in one unit of finished goods * x = quantity used in production
=== Depreciation === All depreciation rules can be stated as equations representing their curve over time. The reducing balance method provides one of the more interesting examples.
Using c = cost, t = time, L = life, s = scrap value, Fd = time based depreciation:
: Depr/yr = Fd = c (s/c)(t-L)/L * [L(s/c)1/L] …………… (equation 7)
This equation is better known as the rule: Depreciation per year = Last year's written down value multiplied by a constant %
The limits are 0 < t < L, and the scrap value has to be greater than zero. (For zero use 0.1).
Remembering that time-based depreciation is a fixed cost and usage-based depreciation can be a variable cost, depreciation can easily be added into the model (equation 5).
Thus, the profit model becomes:
: π = pq - [F + F<sub>d</sub> + (mµ + lλ + n + n<sub>d</sub>)q].......... (equation 8)
where, nd = usage (as q) based depreciation and π = annual profit.
=== Stock valuation === In the above, the value of the unit finished goods cost ‘w' was left undefined. There are numerous alternatives to how stock (w) is valued but only two will be compared here.
The marginal versus absorption costing debate, includes the question of the valuation of stock (w).
Should w = v or as (3) w = (Fm + v x)/x.
(i) Under marginal costing: w = v. Inserting in (4),
: π = pq- [F + v x + g<sub>0</sub>w<sub>0</sub> - g<sub>1</sub> w<sub>1</sub>]
Becomes
: π = pq- [F + v x + g<sub>0</sub>w<sub>0</sub> - g<sub>1</sub> v]
This can be simplified by taking v out and noting, opening stock quantity + production - closing stock quantity = sales quantity (q) so,
: π = p q - [F + v q]………….. (equation 9)
Note, v q = variable cost of goods sold.
(ii) Using full (absorption) costing Using (equation 3), where xp = planned production, x1 = period production w = (Fm + v xp)/xp = Fm/xp + v. This can be shown to result in:
: π = p q - [F<sub>n</sub> + F<sub>m</sub> + v q + F<sub>m</sub>/x<sub>p</sub> * (q-x<sub>1</sub>)]………..(equation 10)
Note the strange presence of 'x' in the model. Notice also that the absorption model (equation 10) is the same as the marginal costing model (equation 9) except for the end part: : F/x<sub>p</sub> * (q-x<sub>1</sub>)
This part represents the fixed costs in stock. This is better seen by remem¬bering q — x= go—g1 so it could be written
:F/x<sub>p</sub> • (g<sub>0</sub>—g<sub>1</sub>)
The model form with 'q' and 'x' in place of' g<sub>0</sub> and g<sub>1</sub> allows profits to be calculated when only the sales and production figures are known.
A spreadsheet could be prepared for a company with increasing then decreasing levels of sales and constant production. It could have another column showing profit under increasing sales and constant production. Thus the effects of carrying fixed costs in stock can be simulated. Such modelling thus provides a very useful tool in the marginal versus full costing debate.
=== Modelling for losses === One way of modeling for losses is to use:
*Fixed losses, (quantity) = δf, *Variable losses (%) = δv, *Material losses = mδ, *Production losses = pδ
The model, with all these losses together will look like,
: π = v q – [F + µ * mδf + {mµ(1 + mδv) + lλ+n) * (1+ pδ* (q +pδf)]........ (equation 11)
Note that labour and variable overhead losses could also have been included.
=== Multi-products === So far the model has assumed very few products and/or cost elements. As many firms are multi-product the model they use must be able to handle this problem. Whilst the mathematics here is straightforward the accounting problems introduced are enormous: the cost allocation problem being a good example. Other examples include calculation of break-even points, productivity measures and the optimisation of limited resources. Here only the mechanics of building a multi-dimension model will be outlined.
If a firm sells two products (a and b) then the profit model (equation 9),
: π = pq —(F +vq) becomes
: π = (pa *qa +pb *qb) - [F + va*qa + vb *qb]
All fixed costs have been combined in F
Therefore, for multiple products
: π = Σ(pq) - [F + Σ(vq)].... (equation 12)
Where Σ = the sum of. Which can be drafted as a vector or matrix in a spreadsheet
or
: π = Σpq - [F + Σ(Σmμ +Σlλ + Σn)q]..... (equation 13)
=== Variances === The profit model may represent actual data (c), planned data (p)or standard data (s) which is the actual sales quantities at the planned costs.
The actual data model will be (using equation 8):
: π = p<sub>c</sub>*q<sub>c</sub> - [F<sub>c</sub> + (mµ<sub>c</sub> + lλ<sub>c</sub> + n<sub>c</sub>)q<sub>c</sub>]
The planned data model will be (using equation 8):
: π = p<sub>p</sub>*q<sub>p</sub> - [F<sub>p</sub> + (mµ<sub>p</sub> + lλ<sub>p</sub> + n<sub>p</sub>)q<sub>p</sub>]
The standard data model will be (using equation 8):
: π = p<sub>p</sub>*q<sub>c</sub> - [F<sub>p</sub> + (mµ<sub>p</sub> + lλ<sub>p</sub> + n<sub>p</sub>)q<sub>c</sub>]
Operating variances are obtained by subtracting the actual model from the standard model.
=== Learning Curve Model === It is possible to add non linear cost curves to the Profit model. For example, if with learning, the labour time per unit will decrease exponentially over time as more product is made, then the time per unit is:
: l = r * q<sup>−b</sup>
where r = average time. b = learning rate. q = quantity.
Inserting into equation 8
: π = pq - [F + (mµ + rq<sup>−b</sup>λ + n)q]
This equation is best solved by trial and error, the [[Newton's method|Newton Raphson method]] or graphing. Like depreciation within the model, the adjustment for learning does provide a form of non-linear sub-modelling.
=== Percentage Change Model === Rather than the variable be absolute amounts, they might be percentage changes. This represents a major change in approach from the model above. The model is often used in the 'now that ... (say) the cost of labour has gone up by 10%' format. If a model can be developed that only uses such percentage changes then the cost of collecting absolute quantities will be saved.<ref>Eilon, S. (1984), ''The Art of Reckoning: analysis of performance criteria'', London: Academic Press</ref>
The notation used below is of attaching a % sign to variables to indicate the change of that variable, for example, p% = 0.10 if the selling price is assumed to change by 10%,
Let x = q and C = contribution
Starting with the absolute form of the contribution model (equation (9) rearranged):
: π + F = C = (p — v)q.
The increase in the contribution which results from an increase in p, v and/or q can be calculated thus:
: C(l + C%) = [p(l+p%)- v(l + v%)]q(l+q%)
rearranging and using α = (p — v)/p,
: C% = ((l+q%)/α)[p%-(l - α)v%]+q%...... (equation 18)
This model might look messy but it is very powerful. It makes very few demands on data, especially if some of the variables do not change. It is possible to develop most of the models presented above in this percentage change format.

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} '''''RBK Daily''''' is a general [[Business journalism|business newspaper]] published in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]].
==History and profile== ''RBK Daily'' was started in October 2006.<ref name=kat>{{cite journal|author=Katja Koikkalainen|title=The Local and the International in Russian Business Journalism: Structures and Practices|journal=Europe-Asia Studies|date=December 2007|volume=59|issue=8|jstor=20451455}}</ref> The paper is part of [[RBC Information Systems|RosBusinessConsulting]] and is published by the company in cooperation with the German publishing group Handelsblatt<ref>{{cite web|title=RBC's business branches|url=http://www.rbcnews.com/company.shtml|work=RBC-RosBusinessConsulting|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=pubf>{{cite web|title=PBK Daily. Factsheet|url=http://www.publicitas.com/it/austria/media-solutions/factsheet/mediadata/rbk-daily/?PARAM1=ROERM2#.VTEtfZSsXRA|publisher=Publicitas|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref> The daily has its headquarters in Moscow.<ref name=pubf/>
''RBK Daily'' is published full-color unlike most of newspapers published in Russia and other business papers.<ref name=kat/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rbcdaily.ru/ Official website]

{{nofootnotes|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
'''Rajagiri National Business Quiz''', popularly known as [http://rajagirinbq.com/ RajagiriNBQ], is the quiz conclave of Rajagiri Centre for Business Studies, Cochin. A major highlight of its management fest INFLORE, Rajagiri NBQ took shape in 2010 and has continued to grow in the subsequent years where it provides a concrete platform for various teams to showcase their skill and knowledge. Rajagiri National Business Quiz sees the best quizzing minds of the country. It creates an environment of high competition between the Corporates and students and offers a separate forum for both. Being one of the most sought-after quizzing event in the country. Rajagiri is all geared up to host its seventh edition of Rajagiri National Business Quiz this year.
== Growth and Inception ==
[[Rajagiri]] Centre for business studies is one among the pioneer institutions in management education in South India. Ranked among the top B-schools in the country Rajagiri strives relentlessly towards excellence in both academic and extracurricular activities. The CMI fathers who run this institution aim at chartering new systems of high quality in the field of education.[1] Apart from [[Rajagiri]], the CMI fathers manage over 500 educational institutions across the country. [[Rajagiri]] has an impressive track record for producing the best minds of today and this is reflected in the quizzing event, [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri NBQ].
[http://rajagirinbq.com/ RAJAGIRI NBQ] which began its journey in 2010, is one of the most successful, fully student-driven quiz events of the country. Over the years its quality began to attract participants from around the country and successfully established itself as the quiz conclave that brings corporate and students together and enable battle of the best. Though it started with a common prize for both categories, the separate allocation was brought in gradually. Rajagiri NBQ drew a footfall of over 1500 registrations to compete with the trivia knowledge to earn around 3.7 lakhs cash prize in its 6th edition. Yearly choice of unique theme, well organized by a group of proficient and fervent students adds to its value. The first five editions of [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri NBQ] was hosted by the quiz master, Mr. [https://www.linkedin.com/in/rohitsnair Rohit Nair] from Quiz works while the sixth edition was taken over by Mr. [https://www.linkedin.com/in/agarwalmitesh Mitesh Agarwal], Vice President and CTO [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] India.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2017 === The theme for 2017 Rajagiri NBQ was 'The Charging Bull' that symbolizes the uptrend which shows how sensational this event was. The economic prosperity is taken to an all new level. A fully student-run initiative and one of a kind among the business school campuses across India, Rajagiri NBQ’s 8th edition set new records with over 2300 registrations from both online and offline prelims. The Quizmaster was [https://www.linkedin.com/in/agarwalmitesh Mitesh Agarwal], Vice President & CTO, Oracle India. The chief guest for the event was Paul Antony, Additional Chief Secretary, Government of Kerala. The official media partner for the year was [[NDTV|NDTV 24x7]].
Nexus Consulting, Bangalore ( Corporate Category) and Osmania Medical College (Student Category) emerged winners of this edition of Rajagiri NBQ. [[Tata Consultancy Services|TCS]], Chennai (Corporate Category) and [[NIT Silchar|NIT Silchar]] (Student Category) were the First Runners Up.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2016 ===
The 7th edition of the Rajagiri NBQ had 'Castling' a move in the game of Chess as its theme. The event scaled up to higher levels with over 1600 participants in both corporate and student categories. Just as the theme for the edition, all the teams competed against each other to safeguard their positions in the game, all throughout. Rajagiri NBQ had prizes worth Rs. 3.8 Lakhs this time; was hosted by Mr [https://www.linkedin.com/in/agarwalmitesh Mitesh Agarwal], Vice President and CTO [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] India.
Nexus Consulting, Bangalore ( Corporate Category) and NIT Rourkela (Student Category) emerged winners of this edition of Rajagiri NBQ. [[Tata Consultancy Services|TCS]], Chennai (Corporate Category) and Guwahati University (Student Category) were the First Runners Up. The Chennai Silks, Coimbatore and Government Law College, Ernakulam were the Second Runners Up in the Corporate and Student categories respectively.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2015 ===
The theme for Rajagiri NBQ,2015 was [[World domination|World Domination]](Risk), which is an exciting board game combining the classic elements of trivia, travel, and money in one entertaining game. The game revolves around eliminating your opponents by conquering their territory and overthrowing them. Similarly Rajagiri National Business Quiz, 2015 was a riveting quiz game where the players battled for the ultimate victory. To be the ultimate winner the players had to dominate over several regions of knowledge like finance, current affairs, international knowledge, corporate knowledge, etc. This year’s winners emerged from [[Tata Consultancy Services|TCS]], Chennai and [[Osmania Medical College]] from corporate and student sections respectively who took away Rs. 1 Lakh each.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2014 === With the [[Monopoly Game|game of monopoly]], Rajagiri National Business Quiz received nationwide acclaim for having over 600 registrations from both corporate and student category in this edition.[2] Sixteen teams were handpicked to the semi-finals on the basis of their prelims performance. This year saw separate sections for both corporates and students with separate prize money of Rs 1, 00,000 awarded to the first prize winners and Rs 50,000 for the second prize. Genpact nabbed the prize money in the corporate section and Christ University in the student’s section.[3][4] [https://www.linkedin.com/in/k-g-girish-babu-28aa2059 K.G. Girish Babu], (CEO, [[Technopark, Trivandrum|Technopark]], Kerala) was the chief guest for this year. The nationwide participation of well-known corporates and leading management institutions made [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri NBQ] 2014 a grand success.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2013 === The 2013 [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri NBQ] which revolved around the game of Cards, received over 800 registrations from both corporate and students. The quizmaster Mr. Rohit Nair managed 16 teams, who had cleared the prelims and got themselves into the finals. Oracle won the first position followed by TCS with a prize of Rs.75, 000, [http://www.simc.edu/ SIMC] Pune with Rs.50, 000 and [http://www.christuniversity.in/ Christ University] Bangalore with Rs 30,000. Mr. S Ravi Shankar, (General Manager of main event partner - [[Lakshmi Vilas Bank]]) presided over the event.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2012 === [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri National Business Quiz], 2012 went nationwide with a change of format from a single event to five events. Mr. Rohit Nair piloted the quiz in the new format consisting of three online prelims, zonal for students in Guwahati, Hyderabad and Chennai, offline prelims, Semi-finals, and Finals. [[Tata Consultancy Services|TCS]] Chennai won the 1st Prize of Rs. 1, 00,000 for the second year running defending their title and Oracle, Bangalore was the runner-up with a prize money worth Rs. 50,000. 2012 witnessed around 500 teams.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2011 === Rajagiri National Business Quiz 2011 was conducted in the valley campus on 19 November 2011. The quiz was conducted in the same format as the preceding year. [[Tata Consultancy Services|TCS]], Chennai bagged the 1st prize of Rs1, 00,000 followed by Symbiosis Law School, Pune winning Rs. 50,000.
=== Rajagiri NBQ 2010 === The first ever [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri National Business Quiz] was launched on 30 October 2010. The quiz had 3 rounds –prelims, semi-finals, and finals which was overseen by the quiz master Mr. Rohit Nair. The competition was intense between the corporates and the students to win the much sought-after prize of Rs 1, 00,000 and Rs 50,000 for first and second prize respectively. [[Cognizant|Cognizant Technologies]] (CTS), Bangalore walked away with Rs 1, 00,000 victory and the second prize of Rs 50,000 was bagged by CET, Trivandrum. Mr. Ravi Shankar, (General Manager of main event partner - Lakshmi Vilas Bank) was the chief guest for the event. The massive response received from top corporates and the leading educational institutions in the country made [http://rajagirinbq.com/ Rajagiri National Business Quiz] 2010 a roaring success paving the way for the quizzes that were yet to come.
== Media and Publicity ==
RAJAGIRI NBQ is one of the most anticipated quizzing events of the country and often showcases the management skill of Rajagirians in general. The fest has attracted a large amount of coverage from the electronic and print media. CNN-IBN being its media partner for the last five editions Rajagiri NBQ has attracted considerable media attention. Times Now was the media partner for the sixth edition of the event. Numerous articles have appeared about Rajagiri NBQ in various newspapers all over India.
== Recognition ==
Featuring a wide range of quality arrows that test the mettle of top B-School and corporate brains, RNBQ was rated among the top 3 most popular events in India by Dare2Compete in 2012.
== Rounds ==
RNBQ is a team based contest with two participants per team and is held in 2 laps. Corporate and campus representatives who qualify the prelims (online/offline) enter into the final lap. The second lap, the national finals are held for Campus students and corporate separately. Ten editions of RNBQ have been held so far too enthusiastic response.
== Notable guests ==
Every year many esteemed personalities of different fields from around the country are invited as guests of honor. Some of the prominent guests to participate in the event are K.G. Girish Babu, (CEO, Info park), Mr. S Ravi Shankar, (General Manager - Lakshmi Vilas Bank).
== Sponsors ==
Rajagiri NBQ is a completely student-driven event where the students find the sponsors to fund the show. The major sponsors of Rajagiri NBQ over the years are Lakshmi Villas Bank, Idea Cellular Ltd, Nissan, e-Bay, Deccan Chronicle, Jos Alukkas and many more.

{{Insolvency}} A '''secured creditor''' is a [[creditor]] with the benefit of a [[security interest]] over some or all of the assets of the [[debtor]].
In the event of the [[bankruptcy]] of the debtor, the secured creditor can enforce security against the assets of the debtor and avoid competing for a distribution on liquidation with the [[unsecured creditor]]s.
In most legal systems, secured creditors also have the option of releasing their security and proving in the [[liquidation]], although, in practice, they would rarely do so.
==See also== * [[Preferential creditor]]

page.title: Small and medium-sized enterprises in Azerbaijan

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
[[Small and medium-sized enterprises]] are called as KOS (kiçik və orta sahibkarlıq) or KOM (kiçik və orta müəssisələr) in [[Azerbaijan]]. SMEs have a leading position in the provision of economic growth and employment in Azerbaijan.
== Classification of SMEs == Azerbaijan also gave their categorization both relating to the amount of employees work at the company and annual turnover. Categorization of enterprises is indicated like below:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taxes.gov.az/modul.php?name=qanun&news=1091|title=- Qanunvericilik|website=Taxes.Gov.Az|language=en|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |'''Categorization of enterprises relating to their size''' |'''Number of employees''' |'''Annual turnover (AZN)''' |- |Small enterprises |< 25 |< 200 000 |- |Medium-sized enterprises |25 < 125 |200 000 < 1 250 000 |- |Large enterprises |125 < |1 250 000 < |} Governmental Statistic Committee defined this classification by taking into account various economic fields as below.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stat.gov.az/source/entrepreneurship/?lang=en|title=Small entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan {{!}} The State Statistical Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan|last=(www.anarsamadov.net)|first=Anar Samadov|date=|website=The State Statistical Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |'''The category of entrepreneurship''' |'''Size of employees''' |'''Annual turnover (AZN)''' |- |Industry and construction |< 50 |< 500 000 |- |Agriculture |< 25 |< 250 000 |- |Wholesale trade |< 15 |< 1000 000 |- |Retail trade, transport,
service and other economic activities
types |< 10 |< 250 000 |} Small and medium-sized enterprises divided into two groups in Azerbaijan. * Individual entrepreneurs, so without creating legal person the sole owner of the enterprise. Individual entrepreneurs are persons involved in the business sphere without the formation of any legal entity and possess unlimited liability. * Small and medium-sized enterprises, that is, legal entities, which individual entrepreneurs legally considered as small businesses. Individuals who registered as a legal person classifies according to two kinds of indicators: the amount of employees and in accordance with its annual turnover. In term of the number of enterprises and employees, individual enterprises occupy the main part of the small and medium-sized business field. According to the data of the Statistics Committee for the year 2015, the number of small businesses in all economic sectors of the country, was 196 327. The number of small entrepreneurs has increased in 2015 about 9 429 people compared to 2014. In addition, 178 163 of them were individual entrepreneurs. Individual entrepreneur mostly agglomerated in the sectors, especially trade, and where take more revenues instead of minimum investments. Only a little amount of entrepreneurs takes part in business activities, which require high early investments and make profit in a long-term. On average, individual entrepreneurs employ less people and by this way, they decrease their expenditures and make more profit.
Legal entities registered by central administrations of ministries and agencies, and inspected carefully by them. Small enterprise is an entrepreneurship that controlled by legal entity and indicated in the disposal of the Ministry Cabinet. In this disposal the main principles for small and medium-sized enterprises are indicated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cesd.az/new/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/CESD_Report-SMEs_Azerbaijan.pdf|title=Small and Medium Entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan; Country Assessment|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Programs for SME development == Direct the development of entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan started in 1990s. On December 12, 1992 government established "Regulations of the Republic of Azerbaijan National Entrepreneurship Support Fund". The approval of this fund let small and medium-sized enterprises take advantage from preferential loans. However, until 2001 the mechanism of the delivery to the entrepreneurship entities did not work properly. [[Heydar Aliyev]]’s on August 27, 2002 issued decree resulted the approval of "Regulations on National Entrepreneurship Support Fund of Azerbaijan Republic" and " The use of fund of National Entrepreneurship Support Fund of Azerbaijan Guidelines” was directed to the development of a mechanism for financing of investment projects of entrepreneurs. The began to issue loans with lower interest rates in the national currency, as well as, identification of the grace period to the first two-thirds parts of loans and credit’s low percentage caused arising interest to these credits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://anfes.gov.az/en/|title=Azerbaijan Ministry Of Economy National Fund For Entrepreneurship Support|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Strategic road map for the development of SMEs ===
SME development in the country based on the Strategic Road Map defined in order to achieve the strategic goals and to ensure maximum use of the opportunities identified as a strategic objective as follows:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mida.gov.az/documents/Ki%C3%A7ik_v%C9%99_orta_sahibkarl%C4%B1q_s%C9%99viyy%C9%99sind%C9%99_istehlak_mallar%C4%B1n%C4%B1n_istehsal%C4%B1na_dair.pdf|title=Strategic Road Map of Azerbaijan for the Production and Consumption of Goods at the Level of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Further improvement of the regulatory framework in the business environment in order to enhance the impact of the SME into [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] * Ensuring affordable and effective access to financing resources in order to create a sustainable network of SMEs * Internationalization of SMEs and increase access to foreign markets in order to increase the country's foreign exchange reserves and ensure compliance with international standards of goods produced in the country * Increasing the supply of quality products and services within the development of skilled workforce and development of SMEs focusing on regional markets * Strengthening of research and development and promotion of innovation in order to increase the competitiveness of SMEs Strategic Road Map defines the short, medium and long term directions of the economic reforms and development in SMEs. There are three main strategic views:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ecoreform.az/store//media/islahat_icmali/aprel/SME_eng.pdf|title=AZERBAIJAN ECONOMIC REFORMS REVIEW|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * until 2020 * the long-term view until 2025 * target view since 2025
=== Single window principle ===
[[Single-window system|"Single window" system]] applied based on the presidential decree issued on April 30, 2007. This principle provided for the registration of business entities and started to implement their online registration. Based on the principle [[E-government|E-Government]] portal has been created and implementation of the system started in 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://azertag.az/en/xeber/UNECE_HOLDS_SEMINAR_ON_SINGLE_WINDOW_PRINCIPLE_IN_BAKU-593335|title=UNECE HOLDS SEMINAR ON "SINGLE WINDOW" PRINCIPLE IN BAKU|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of companies of Azerbaijan]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox Officeholder | name = Tibor Antalpéter | image = | caption = | order = [[List of Ambassadors of Hungary to the United Kingdom|Hungarian Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] | term_start = 1990 | term_end = 1995 | president = | predecessor = [[József Györke]] | successor = [[Tádé Alföldy]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1930|02|04}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|09|15|1930|02|04}} | death_place = | parents = István Antalpéter
Viktória Dobai | alma_mater = Calvinist Grammar School (Budapest)
[[Corvinus University of Budapest|Karl Marx University]] | occupation = economist | spouse = Adél Mátha | children = Katalin
Sára | profession = volleyball player | party = |}} {{eastern name order|Antalpéter Tibor}} '''Tibor Antalpéter''' (4 February 1930 – 15 September 2012){{cite web |url=http://hvg.hu/itthon/20120915_Elhunyt_volt_londoni_nagykovetunk_Antalpe |title=Elhunyt volt londoni nagykövetünk, Antalpéter Tibor |accessdate=2012-09-16|date=2012-09-15 |publisher=[[Heti Világgazdaság]]}} was a [[Hungarians|Hungarian]] volleyball player who played for [[Csepel SC]] and the [[Hungary men's national volleyball team|Hungarian national team]]. He served as Hungarian Ambassador to the [[United Kingdom]] from 1990 to 1995.{{cite news|author=George Gomori |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/08/tibor-antalpeter-obituary |title=Tibor Antalpéter obituary | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 8 October 2012|accessdate=2012-10-09 |location=London}} ==Biography== He was born in [[Budapest]] on 4 February 1930. His parents were István Antalpéter and Viktória Dobai. He married Adél Mátha in 1956. They had two daughters: Katalin (b. 1958) and Sára (b. 1961). He finished his secondary studies at the Calvinist Grammar School in Budapest. He graduated from the [[Corvinus University of Budapest|Karl Marx University of Economic Sciences]] in 1954. ===Sports career=== Antalpéter was a player of the Csepel SC from 1948 to 1960. He competed at the [[1949 FIVB Men's Volleyball World Championship|FIVB Men's Volleyball World Championship in 1949]] where the team reached a seventh place. His best result is a third place from the [[1950 Men's European Volleyball Championship]]. Two years later, the national team became fifth in the [[1952 FIVB Men's Volleyball World Championship]]. He appeared in 64 international matches for the Hungarian national team since making his debut in 1947 until 1956. He won the National Championship seven times. He served as coach of the adult team of Csepel SC between 1960 and 1969 which won the National Championship twice. He was a Board Member of the Hungarian Volleyball Federation since 1966. He functioned as leader of the Coaches' Committee from 1966 to 1970. He served as Vice President (1970–1973) then President (1981–1986) of the Federation. He was also a member of the [[Hungarian Olympic Committee]] between 1980 and 1986. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * ''Ki kicsoda a magyar sportéletben? , I. kötet (A–H).'' [[Szekszárd]], Babits Kiadó, 1994, p. 43. {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{succession box | before=[[József Györke]] | title=[[List of Ambassadors of Hungary to the United Kingdom|Hungarian Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] | years=1990–1995| after=[[Tádé Alföldy]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Antalpeter, Tibor}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Hungarian diplomats]] [[Category:Hungarian men's volleyball players]] [[Category:Hungarian sports coaches]] [[Category:Volleyball coaches]] [[Category:Hungarian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Hungary to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People from Budapest]] [[Category:Corvinus University of Budapest alumni]]

2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/10/06/10/winners-first-celebrity-style-awards-bared |title=Winners of first Celebrity Style awards bared |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |language= |trans-title=|date=October 6, 2010 |work=www.abs-cbnNEWS.com |publisher=ABS-CBN |accessdate=November 28, 2013}} | box_width = }} '''Timothy "Tim" Yap''' (born January 17, 1977) is a Filipino TV and radio host, newspaper editor, creative director, columnist, club owner and eventologist from [[Metro Manila|Manila]], [[Philippines]]. He also owns several clubs in the Philippines. He currently hosts ''The Tim Yap Show'' which airs weeknights on [[GMA-7]], edits a pop culture section of ''[[The Philippine Star]]'' entitled "Supreme", and hosted the morning radio talk show ''The Playground'' on 99.5 PLAYFM. ==Early life and career== Tim Yap was the youngest of seven kids.{{cite web |url=http://www.philstar.com/sunday-life/2013/10/20/1247090/tim-yap-shy-guy-celebrity |title=Tim Yap: From shy guy to celebrity |last1=Gonzalez |first1=Bianca |last2= |first2= |language= |trans-title=|date=October 20, 2013 |work=www.philstar.com |publisher=The Philippine Star |accessdate=November 2, 2013}} While attending high school at [[Saint Jude Catholic School (Manila)|Saint Jude Catholic School]], he won the lead role in [[Lost in Yonkers]], which marked the 25th anniversary of the Repertory Philippines, but his parents and his school didn’t allow him to go, so he attended rehearsals in secret, informing the school security guard that he had the permission of his teacher and principal to leave school. "My parents had no clue that I was going to Repertory," he said. "All along they thought that I was just attending a rehearsal for a school play until they read about it in the newspapers." After several roles for young characters, Yap continued on as a production intern for repertory plays just to be involved. He eventually evolved into an events producer, which led him to be sought after to handle product launches and [[fashion show]]s. Yap graduated from [[De La Salle University]] with a bachelor's degree in marketing, and later on received his master's degree in entrepreneurship from the [[Asian Institute of Management]]. He edited the "Super" section of the ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'', and then left the ''Inquirer'' to start the "Supreme" section of the ''[[Philippine Star]]''. Tim Yap hosted the Metro Manila Film Festival Awards in 2010 and 2011. He hosted Miss World Philippines in 2011. On January 21, 2013, ''The Tim Yap Show'' premiered on [[GMA-7]], with Yap as the host of the self-titled celebrity talk show. It is currently in its third season, which premiered Oct. 28, 2013. Aside from television appearances, he hosted the morning radio talk The Playground on 99.5 PLAYFM with [[Sam Oh]] and Nikko Ramos. ==Awards== His show has also won "Best Lifestyle Show" for three consecutive years at the PMPC Star Awards. In 2010,In 2013, he was awarded Outstanding Young Filipino in Entrepreneurship by Gawad Amerika.{{cite web |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/international/articles/2013-11-26/221/KAPUSO-ABROAD-12th-Gawad-Amerika-Awards-Gives-Top-Citations-To-Kapuso-Celebrities |title=KAPUSO ABROAD: 12th Gawad Amerika Awards Gives Top Citations To Kapuso Celebrities |date=November 26, 2013 |publisher=[[GMA Network]] |accessdate=November 28, 2013}} ==Advocacy== Since 2008, Yap has been an active supporter of the [[Virlaine Foundation]], a non-government organization engaged in helping street children. In 2011, he spearheaded the ''Rice Up for Street Children'' campaign after having been named as the foundation's Ambassador of Goodwill. ==Personal life== Yap is engaged to his long-time boyfriend Javi Martinez Pardo. He proposed to Javi shortly after his 40th birthday on January 19, 2017. The couple got married at December 25, 2017 at New York City.{{cite news|last1=Tantiangco|first1=Aya|title=Tim Yap proposes to his boyfriend|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/596459/lifestyle/tim-yap-proposes-to-his-boyfriend|accessdate=20 January 2017|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|date=20 January 2017}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:56%;" |- ! style="width:30px"| Year ! style="width:200px"| Title ! style="width:100px"| Role ! class="unsortable"| Notes |- | 2003 | ''Anghel sa Lupa'' | Raphael | Produced by Regal Entertainment |- | 2004 | ''[[Mano Po III: My Love]]'' | Chinese Opera Director | Produced by Regal Entertainment through MAQ Productions;
